episodeTitle: Finally Time to Go! Goodbye, Fish-Man Island!
description: The Straw Hat Pirates prepare to depart Fish-Man Island and enter the New World. Nami receives a special three-needle Log Pose for navigating unpredictable New World waters. Shirahoshi makes an emotional promise with Luffy to reunite someday, and the crew bids farewell to their friends as they set sail toward their greatest adventure yet.

events.title: Madame Sharley Destroys Her Crystal Ball
events.description: At the Mermaid Cafe, Madame Sharley's shattered crystal ball lies on the floor. She deliberately broke it herself, stating she no longer needs it. The vision of Luffy surrounded by fire haunted her, and she expresses that if she never sees that vision again, she would be happy.
events.significance: This symbolizes Sharley's hope that her prophecy about Luffy destroying Fish-Man Island won't come true, despite her visions always being accurate. The broken crystal ball represents her choosing hope over fate.

quotes.text: I no longer need it. If I never see that vision again, I would be very happy.
quotes.speaker: Madame Sharley
quotes.context: Explaining why she destroyed her crystal ball after her prophecy about Luffy

events.title: Introduction of the New World Log Pose
events.description: The Minister of the Left presents Nami with a special three-needle Log Pose designed for navigating the New World. Unlike the standard single-needle version, this Log Pose points to three different islands simultaneously, with needle movement intensity indicating danger levels.
events.significance: This marks a crucial upgrade in navigation technology for the Straw Hats as they prepare to enter the unpredictable waters of the New World. The three-needle system allows them to choose their route and assess danger levels.

quotes.text: In the New World, you need a triple needle pose because islands there alter their magnetic waves so frequently - some disappearing altogether. The more erratic a needle's movement, the more dangerous the island.
quotes.speaker: Minister of the Left
quotes.context: Explaining the New World Log Pose to Nami

events.title: Luffy Chooses the Most Dangerous Route
events.description: After listening to the Minister of the Left's explanation about the New World Log Pose, Luffy wraps his neck around Nami and points to the needle that moves the most erratically, declaring that will be their next destination since it's the most dangerous.
events.significance: This moment perfectly encapsulates Luffy's fearless leadership style and his preference for the most challenging path. It sets the tone for their New World adventure and causes concern among the more cautious crew members.

quotes.text: That will be our next destination since it's the most dangerous!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Choosing the most erratic needle on the New World Log Pose

events.title: Neptune's Secret About the Tamatebako
events.description: Neptune and the Minister of the Right discuss the Tamatebako treasure box that was given to Big Mom's crew. The Minister reveals it contains a bomb that will explode if opened. Neptune is shocked but decides not to tell the Straw Hats, hoping that after ten years, the explosives might have become duds.
events.significance: This plants a crucial plot device that will pay off dramatically in the future during Big Mom's wedding celebration. The bomb-laden treasure box represents a ticking time bomb in the story, literally and figuratively.

quotes.text: It was ten years since the bomb was placed in there. It may have become a dud.
quotes.speaker: Neptune
quotes.context: Hoping the bomb in the Tamatebako won't explode

events.title: Luffy and Shirahoshi's Pinky Promise
events.description: Shirahoshi swims up to the Thousand Sunny and asks Luffy to take her for another walk someday, but next time on the surface to see a real forest. She promises not to be a crybaby and holds out her pinky. Luffy wraps his pinky around hers, making the promise. Most of the crew members (except Zoro and Franky) join by touching their pinkies to hers.
events.significance: This emotional promise foreshadows a future reunion and symbolizes the Straw Hats' commitment to helping Shirahoshi achieve her dream of seeing the surface world. It also demonstrates the crew's collective acceptance of promises made by their captain.

quotes.text: I will not be a crybaby next time we meet! I want to go on another walk with you, but this time on the surface to see a real forest!
quotes.speaker: Shirahoshi
quotes.context: Making a promise with Luffy before his departure

quotes.text: A promise is something you have to keep. If that was Luffy's decision, we will help him honor his promise to Shirahoshi.
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Explaining why the crew joins the pinky promise

events.title: The Hero Hat - Straw Hats as Symbol of Hope
events.description: A Fish-Man child asks his father for a straw hat to play heroes, but his father says they're only available on the surface. Jinbe overhears and promises to send a merchant ship to get straw hats for the children. This demonstrates how Luffy has become a hero to Fish-Man Island's residents.
events.significance: The straw hat evolves from being Luffy's personal treasure to a symbol of heroism and hope for the people of Fish-Man Island. This moment ties to the chapter title 'The Hero Hat' and shows Luffy's impact on those he helps.

events.title: Luffy Reflects on His Straw Hat's Meaning
events.description: As the crew prepares to depart, Luffy reflects on his straw hat and remembers the day Shanks gave it to him. He also recalls words of encouragement from Ace, Jinbe, and Rayleigh. Luffy expresses excitement about being in the same ocean as Shanks.
events.significance: This introspective moment reinforces the deep emotional connection Luffy has to his straw hat and the people who have shaped his journey. It serves as a bridge between his past training and his future adventures in the New World.

quotes.text: We will be in the same ocean as Shanks when we reach the surface. I'm looking forward to seeing him.
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Reflecting on entering the New World where Shanks operates

events.title: Straw Hats Depart Fish-Man Island
events.description: The Straw Hat Pirates officially depart Fish-Man Island, sailing upward through the ocean toward the New World. The residents of Fish-Man Island gather to wave goodbye, marking the end of the Fish-Man Island arc and the beginning of their New World journey.
events.significance: This marks the conclusion of the first major arc post-time skip and the crew's official entry into the New World, where the stakes are higher and the enemies more dangerous. It's a turning point in the series.

quotes.text: I will not be a crybaby next time we meet! I want to go on another walk with you, but this time on the surface to see a real forest!
quotes.speaker: Shirahoshi

quotes.text: A promise is something you have to keep. If that was Luffy's decision, we will help him honor his promise to Shirahoshi.
quotes.speaker: Brook

quotes.text: That will be our next destination since it's the most dangerous!
quotes.speaker: Luffy
quotes.context: Choosing their route through the New World

themes.description: The episode heavily emphasizes the importance of promises, from Shirahoshi's pinky promise with Luffy to the crew's collective commitment to honor it. The straw hat itself represents Luffy's promise to Shanks.
themes.symbolism: The pinky promise between Shirahoshi and the crew symbolizes the bonds formed during their time at Fish-Man Island and foreshadows future reunions.
culturalReferences: Pinky promises (yubikiri) are a significant cultural practice in Japan, often used to seal important promises

themes.description: The episode marks a fresh start for the Straw Hats as they prepare to enter the New World, representing both the culmination of their training and the beginning of their greatest challenges.
themes.symbolism: The three-needle Log Pose symbolizes the complexity and unpredictability of the path ahead.

themes.description: The straw hat evolves from Luffy's personal treasure into a symbol of hope and heroism for Fish-Man Island's children, showing how his actions inspire others.
themes.symbolism: The straw hat transforms from a memento of Shanks into a symbol of heroism that children aspire to emulate.

themes.description: Madame Sharley's destruction of her crystal ball represents choosing hope over predetermined fate, even as her prophecy about Luffy remains unfulfilled.
themes.symbolism: The broken crystal ball represents the rejection of fatalism in favor of hope for a better future.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy demonstrates his fearless leadership by choosing the most dangerous route and makes meaningful promises to Shirahoshi. He reflects on his journey and the mentors who shaped him.
keyActions: Chooses the most dangerous route through the New World
Makes a pinky promise with Shirahoshi
Reflects on Shanks, Ace, Jinbe, and Rayleigh's influence
Leads the crew's departure from Fish-Man Island
quotes: That will be our next destination since it's the most dangerous!
We will be in the same ocean as Shanks when we reach the surface.

characterSpotlights.development: Shirahoshi shows growth by promising not to be a crybaby and expressing her dream to see the surface world, demonstrating her courage inspired by Luffy.
keyActions: Swims to the Thousand Sunny to say goodbye
Makes a pinky promise with Luffy and most of the crew
Expresses her dream to visit the surface
quotes: I will not be a crybaby next time we meet! I want to go on another walk with you, but this time on the surface to see a real forest!

characterSpotlights.development: Nami receives the crucial New World Log Pose and must adapt to new navigation challenges, though she's frustrated by Luffy's reckless route choice.
keyActions: Receives the New World Log Pose from the Minister of the Left
Learns about New World navigation complexities
Reacts with concern to Luffy's dangerous route choice

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expanded some emotional farewell scenes with additional character reactions and extended dialogue.

trivia.fact: This episode aired on November 18, 2012, marking the conclusion of the Fish-Man Island arc which began in episode 523.
The episode's corresponding manga chapter is titled 'The Hero Hat,' emphasizing how Luffy's straw hat has become a symbol of heroism to the people of Fish-Man Island.
The three-needle Log Pose introduced in this episode becomes a crucial navigation tool for the Straw Hats throughout their New World journey.
Episode 573 had a TV rating of 10.2% in Japan, ranking 5th for its time slot.
From episode 279 onwards, One Piece stopped using ending themes, so this episode (like others in its era) only featured an opening theme without an ending theme.

sources.title: One Piece Music - One Piece Wiki
